title: Quiz 4: Social Mobility & Mobilisation
description: Test your knowledge on how individuals move up or down the social ladder and the concept of social mobilisation.

questions.question: A general nurse trains as a midwife but receives no change in salary or rank. What type of social mobility is this?
questions.explanation: Horizontal mobility involves a change in role without a change in status level or rewards.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of Vertical Social Mobility?

options.text: Moving from one hospital to another as a staff nurse
A peasant farmer's daughter becoming a graduate nurse
Changing from a teacher to a clerk with the same pay

questions.explanation: Vertical mobility involves moving up (or down) the social hierarchy (e.g., peasant to professional).
questions.hint: Look for a change in status level.

questions.question: Which factors are generally considered to encourage UPWARD social mobility? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Fewer children, late marriage, and mother dominance are associated with upward mobility. Large families and early marriage often hinder it.
questions.hint: Think about resource allocation and planning.

questions.question: Match the type of mobility to its definition:

pairs.right: Results from changes in the distribution of statuses in society (e.g., economic boom)
Individuals trade positions; some rise as others fall
Change in status between father and son

questions.explanation: Structural is due to societal changes. Exchange is a trade-off. Intergenerational is across generations.

questions.question: Social ___BLANK___ is an approach that enables people to organise for collective action by pooling resources to resolve common problems.
questions.explanation: Social mobilisation is the process of organizing communities for collective development.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a key element of social mobilisation?
questions.explanation: Social mobilisation promotes democratic, participatory approaches, not autocratic leadership.
questions.hint: Mobilisation is about empowerment, not control.

questions.question: Community size affects mobility: larger communities often offer greater economic differences and incentives for upward mobility.
questions.explanation: Large cities provide more opportunities and visible economic differences that can motivate mobility.

questions.question: What term refers to the change in status during an individual's own work life (career)?
questions.explanation: Intragenerational mobility refers to changes within a single generation or career.

questions.question: Why is capital formation (savings) important in social mobilisation?

options.text: It allows the government to tax the group
It enhances the organisation's power to realise its full potential and self-reliance

questions.explanation: Savings provide assets for internal credit and enterprise, fostering self-reliance.

questions.question: Social mobility only refers to moving UP the social ladder.
questions.explanation: Social mobility can be upward, downward, or horizontal.
